I am a poor orphan : I never knew a father's care or a mother's love ! I have been driven by poverty and ill usage to herd with men who have forced me into guilt and misery. Do not believe me guilty, for that would kill me; shelter and protect me, and an orphan's blessing will reward you.

sp.speaker: Giles.
sp.p: (to Servants) He don't look so very desperate, does he ?

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: And is it possible that you are alone, unprotected, and forced into crime against your own inclination?

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: Indeed, 'tis true, lady; believe me—oh, believe me!

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Follow me up stairs, and I will question you further. (to Giles) Let Dr. Losberne be sent for, and if this boy's story should be true, he shall not remain unfriended. Follow me, boy.

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: The blessings of a grateful heart be on you, lady. (music. — exit Rose, R. followed by Oliver and Servants)

div.head: Scene II .— Sikes's Lodgings — door, l.
div.stage: A bed, C. on which Sikes is sleeping, Nancy watching him. Chairs and table; music.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: He sleeps now; the fever is leaving him, and he has become more tranquil. Oh, would that I could leave this horrid life of crime and misery! The good lady that I have seen, promised to aid me in my good intentions, and I am to meet her to-night on London Bridge, at twelve o'clock. How shall I keep my appointment without being watched.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: (waking) Nance.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Yes, Bill.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: (sits up on the bed) What's o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Getting on for twelve, Bill. How do you feel now ?

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: As weak as water. Give us a hand to get off this thundering bed, will you ? (she assists him to rise) Gently, do you hear ? (loudly)

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Don't be cross, Bill.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Shall if I like ; why shouldn't I ?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Because you don't know the number of nights I've been watching and caring for you, as if you were a child; and this is the first night you have been anything like yourself, and I'm sure you wouldn't be cross with me now. (weeps)

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: What's the fool crying for now ?—don't be coming over me with any of your woman's nonsense. (knock) See who's at the door. (Nancy opens door L. ; enter Fagin and Dodger, with basket, L.)

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: How are you Bill, my tear ?

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: None the better for seeing you, you old willin.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Don't call names, my tear; but see what I've brought you—show him, Dodger.

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: Look here, Bill; here's a rabbit pie, made of sich werry delicate creeturs that their bones will melt in your mouth, and there's no occasion to pick 'em;—half a pound of gunpowder tea, so precious strong, that if you mix it with biling water it'll go nigh to blow the lid of the teapot off; a pound and a half of moist sugar, that the niggers didn't work at all upon, I 'spose, oh, no! not at all neither; two half-a-kervortern busters, a pound o' double Glo'ster, and to wind up, some of the richest port you ever lushed. (pours out a glass and gives it to Sikes) That's the stuff for trousers.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: (holds out glass) Give us another; I aint got the right taste yet. (Dodger fills his glass )

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Ah ha ! Bill, you'll do now.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Do, you old wagabone! I might ha' been done altogether for what you cared. What do you mean by leaving a cove in this state for three weeks, you old wagabone!

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: I couldn't help it, I couldn't, upon my honour!

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Your what ?—here, give us another glass to wash that down.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Be calm, my tear; I hadn't forgot you.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: It's a lie, you old fence; you wouldn't have come now if you hadn't some work for me to do. If it hadn't been for the girl I might ha' died. Give us some blunt.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: I haven't a mag about me.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Then go home and get it.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Vhy, I haven't got as much—

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: There, I don't want to know how much you've got, and I dare say you don't know yourself, 'cause it would take you too long to count it; but some money I'll have to-night, and that's flat, old Fagin.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Veil, Bill, I'll send the Dodger home for all the money I have in the vorld, seven and sixpence; here's the key of the table drawer where it is, Dodger.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: (aside ) It must be near twelve; my promise, my promise. (aloud) I'll go for the money, Bill.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: No, you won't; go on, Dodger; and I say, mind you're not too artful for me—don't gammon to lose the money, or—

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: Vot d'ye mean ? Vhy, I'd never deceive a friend for the vorld, (aside) unless he was green enough to let me. Exit, L. D., Nancy is following.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Hollo! where's the gal going?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I want a breath of fresh air, Bill.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Put your head out o' window then.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: No, I want to go out a bit. I shan't be long.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: (snatches off her bonnet) You ain't going—stay where you are.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: If I had a mind to go, it ain't such a thing as a bonnet that would stop me.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: (forces her in chair) Sit down, will you.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Do you know what you are doing.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: In course I do—holding you down in this here chair.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: (aside) My promise ! my promise! (aloud) Fagin, tell him to let me go.

sp.speaker: Fagan.
sp.p: I never interferes 'twixt man and wife, my tear. (aside) If they quarrel, so much the better for me. Good night, my tears. Exit, L. D.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Fagin! Fagin! take me with you! Oh Bill! Bill! if ever you loved me, let me go !

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Why, what ails the gal ? Is she mad ? Be quiet.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Let me go—let me go !

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: I shan't. (clock strikes twelve)

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: There, there! twelve o'clock! My promise! my promise ! Too late ! too late! (closed in)

div.head: Scene III.— Mr. Bumble's House. (1st grooves)
div.stage: Enter Bumble, L. followed by Monks.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: Now, to business, we drank together last night.

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: We did—we had six glasses of gin and water, warm with sugar.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: Call your wife.

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: (calling off) Here, lovey! this is the gentleman I was telling you of.
This gentleman wants to distort a secret from us, my duck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Perhaps the gentleman thinks a woman cannot keep one.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: There is one secret they will always keep till it is found out—The loss of their good name.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: I don't understand you, sir !

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: Then carry your memory back to that room in the workhouse where misery gives birth to wretched children for the parish to rear upon its stinted bounty.

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: He means the lying-in room, my dear. Ah! a great many children are born there in a very unparochial manner.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: I come to enquire of one named Oliver Twist; his mother died in giving him birth. There was an old hag who nursed her that—

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: Of course there was. You nursed her, didn't you, my dear. (to Mrs. Bumble)

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Silence. No, sir; it was not I, it was Old Sally.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: And where is she ?

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: Why, I think she's dead.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: What reason have you to think so ?

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: Because they buried her.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: Did you see her die.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: No, sir; but I did, and she told me something about the boy's mother.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: Indeed! tell me the truth, and this twenty pound note is yours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Well, sir; Old Sally spoke of a young creature, who had clutched in her hand while dying a small locket, with the name of Agnes engraved inside, also of a wedding ring— I have them in a parcel.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: They are the very things I want.

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: Yes ; but where's the twenty pounds we want?

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: (offers note) Here is the money.

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: (going to take it) Thank you !

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Not so fast. (snatches it) This way, sir.

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: (sighing) Man and wife are one flesh, but they have two pockets. Ah! I've done a good thing for myself, by getting into the himineral halter ! Exit, r.

div.head: Scene IV. — The Stairs and Arch of London Bridge, descended by steps from R.
div.stage: Enter Noah Claypole, in smock frock, followed by Fagin down steps.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Now is the time for you and I to understand each other, my tear.

sp.speaker: Noah.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear it. I've robbed my master, Mr. Sowerberry, and given you twenty pounds to learn me prigging, but don't go shoving me into danger, you know.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: You can dodge a voman, can't you?

sp.speaker: Noah.
sp.p: I believe you ; and whack her too, if that's all.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: It's Nancy I want you to watch, and tell me where she goes, and who she speaks to. I know she's coming here ; I must go and dodge her from Sikes's, and then I'll leave the rest to you—be on the look out.

sp.speaker: Noah.
sp.p: All right! Exit Fagin up steps.

sp.speaker: Noah.
sp.p: I'spose he's doubtful of Nance, as he calls her; afraid she's going to split. I hates a sneak, so I'll watch her and blow the gaff on her. How I hates a suspicious natur. My eye, if old Sowerberry had suspected me, I never could have robbed his till so often. Hark ! footsteps; I'll hide and open my ears and my eyes. (retires, R.)
sp.stage: Music —Nancy, Rose Maylie, and Brownlow descend steps.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: You were not here as you promised?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: It was not my fault, sir, he kept me at home by force.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: Have you heard any more of the man who calls himself Monks ?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I have; a bargain was struck between the Jew and him to make Oliver a thief.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: Did you learn for what purpose ?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I heard the man called Monks say, that " Jew as you are, you will never lay such plans for your victims, as I have for my young brother Oliver."

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: His brother ! What, Oliver !

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Aye, lady, thank heaven, that you had friends to care for and protect you in your infancy—that you never were in the midst of riot, drunkenness, and crime, as I have been since a child ; the alley and the streets have been my cradle and they will be my death-bed.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: Are you not afraid of being watched ?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p:
No, for I gave Bill a dose of laudanum in his drink
before I left. But this let me tell you while I have time, there are certain papers hid in our house by the Jew which Monks gave him to destroy. I know where I can get them, and if I live till to-morrow they shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: Thank you, my good girl, but there is one thing more, you must deliver up this Jew.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: No, devil as he is and worse than devil, I will not do that.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: Well, I will consider how he can be spared, but how can I serve you? I must do something for you.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Don't mind me, sir, I am beyond hope.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: How so? Why not quit your evil companions and accept an asylum at my hands, where you can lead a quiet and contented life.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Too late, sir ! too late! Let us part, and if I have done you any service, all I ask is that you leave me, and let me go my way alone.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: What can be the end of this poor creature's life ?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I will tell you ; look at that dark and rolling river, how many times do you read of such as I springing into its depths and leave no living thing to bewail or regret them, it may be years hence, it may be only months—but be it days, or even weeks before it happens, it will come to that at last! It will never reach your ears, lady, and heaven forbid it should. Let us part, I may be watched or seen.

sp.speaker: Rose.
sp.p: Take this purse.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: No, no, and yet I should like something to remember you by, give me your handkerchief. (Rose gives it) Thank you, thank you! good night and may your good intentions prosper. (going up steps)

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: Nay, nay,—stay.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Follow me not, or you may cause my destruction. Farewell, farewell, and heaven bless you.

div.stage: Music . — They go up the steps. Noah peeps out and threatens them with his fist clenched, and cautiously follows Nancy.

div.head: Scene V.— Front Street. Lights down.
div.stage: Enter Nancy hurriedly, R.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p:
I think I have escaped unnoticed. I hope Bill has not woke. I don't know how it is but I have such a fear and dread upon me to-night, that I can hardly stand, and I can think of nothing else but horrible things of death and misfortune ; but I'll hasten home, and sleep away this gloom; I dreamt too last night, that Fagin would bring me to an untimely end. Oh, how I hate and fear that man, but I must
begone, for should Bill wake, suspicion would fall upon me, and I should be lost. Music — Exit, L.
sp.stage: Enter Sikes, Fagin, and Noah, R.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: And is this true ?

sp.speaker: Noah.
sp.p: As true as I am here, I heard it all.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: And so she's been playing me false, eh? She hocussed me did she! put laudanum in my drink; damn her I'll—

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Be calm, Bill; be calm.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Calm, you withered old fence ! when a girl splits on you, and sells you to the beaks ? Why, none of us are safe now.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Very true, my tear; very true. (aside) If he does her a mischief, so much the better for me, for then I shall get rid of both of them.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: (to Noah) You aint gammoning us, are you ?

sp.speaker: Noah.
sp.p: It's all true as I've told you, 'pon my soul.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Yes, he's a good lad, and has vatched veil; and I've promised to do something handsome for him.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: And I'll do something handsome for her too. (going)

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: (staying him) Don't be rash, Bill.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Keep off, or I'll brain you. If I don't stop her tongue for ever, this night, my name aint Bill Sikes.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Follow him, Noah, and see where he goes—if you hear him quarrelling with Nancy, mind you don't interrupt them—but bring me word all about it.

sp.speaker: Noah.
sp.p: All right, old cock. Exit Noah, L.

sp.speaker: Fagin.
sp.p: Sikes knows too much; de girl knows too much. Vell, vell; I leave them to one another—they'll settle it. Bill may stop her tongue, and then who knows but Sikes may be brought to the gallows, and I not seem to stir in it. Last night I had a dream; I thought I had been condemned to die, and sat in my cell the night before the morning of my execution. I sat in the dark cold cell, and, do what I could, I could not help hearing some one speak, in a loud voice, the words that the judge had said to me, "To be hanged by the neck till I was dead;" and then I thought of the many men I had brought to the same end, and joked at them, too, because I saw them die with a prayer upon their lips.—Some there are who cannot count the number of their loves; I cannot number the number of my hates.—With what a rattling noise the drop goes down, and how suddenly changed from strong and vigorous men to dangling heaps of clothes. "To be hanged by the neck till I am dead !"—and is this—no ! twas a dream, and dreams by contraries go. Be of heart then, Fagin—be of heart, for there are many good years before you yet. Exit, L.

div.head: Scene VI .— Sikes's Garret, as before.
div.stage: Nancy discovered asleep on bed. Music. Enter Sikes, L. door; he puts out the light on table.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: (rouses Nancy) Get up.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: (rises) Is that you, Bill? Oh, I'm so glad! but you've put out the candle.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: There's light enough for what I've got to do.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I'll open the window.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Stay where you are; I want you. (seizes her)

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Oh, tell me what I've done ! I won't scream or cry. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: You know well enough; you've been watched tonight ; I know all about it.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Then spare my life, as I spared yours. Oh, you cannot have the heart to kill to me. I will not loose my hold till you say, you forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Let go, will you?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Stop and hear me. Bill—I have been true to you—I have, upon my guilty soul.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: It's a lie.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: No, it's the truth. The good lady and gentleman told me of a home where I could end my days in peace. Let me see them again, and beg them to show the same mercy to you; we will lead better lives, and forget how wicked we have been—It is never too late to repent—never—never.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Will you let go ?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: No, never, till you say you forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Then die.

div.stage: (strikes her with pistol—a fearful struggle ensues—and he drags her off, R., a pistol shot is heard—a pause, and Sikes re-enters trembling he falls on the bed—a groan is heard, he starts up, goes to, the R. door, looks off, staggers across, and exits, L. D.)

div.head: Scene VII .— Parlor at Mr. Brownlow's. (1st grooves)
div.stage: Enter Mr. Brownlow, followed by Monks, who is brought on by Servants, L.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: By what authority am I brought here ?

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: By mine. Edward Leeford, I was your father's oldest friend; you have a brother, named Oliver.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: 'Tis false—I am an only child.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p:
Your father had issue by another, whom he married under a false name, and then deserted her. She fled from the
world to hide her shame, and in the parish workhouse gave birth to Oliver and expired; soon after your father died, leaving a will.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: He did—bequeathing to myself and my mother the whole of his property.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: False, sir; he left you half only, leaving the other half to Oliver, if he survived. To appropriate the whole, you have sought to destroy the boy, but heaven sent the orphan a protector in me. Now, Edward Leeford, do you brave me still.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: (aside) Perdition ! does he know so much ?

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Brownlow, Nancy has been murdered by Sikes, and the police are seeking him everywhere !

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: (to Monks) Now, sir, here is your wronged brother, take him by the hand, ask for pardon, and all shall be forgotten and forgiven.

sp.speaker: Monks.
sp.p: Never! never! you have triumphed over me, and may my curse rest on you all! Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: He! my brother?—oh let me hasten after him, and—

sp.speaker: Bumb.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Brownlow, here's such a to do—they have tracked the murderer of Nancy to a house by the river side, and the people are running after him to secure him, and —

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Brown, let not the murderer escape!

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: Fear not, my boy, he shall not escape if money or zeal can prevent it—follow me, friends. Music, — Exeunt, L.

div.head: Scene VIII .— At the back, a view of Jacob's Island, with the Thames by moonlight. An old house open to the Audience. The tops of the houses with chimney pots cross the stage. — (See plate in the novel.)
div.stage: Toby and Dodger discovered in room playing at cards, R.C.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: That's mine—so Fagin's nailed, eh?

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: Yes ; they nabbed him just at dinner time. I cut my lucky up the chimney—Charley got into the water butt, but they se'ed his legs sticking out at top and nailed him.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Well, I wish you'd picked out another crib rather than this.

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: Why I thought you'd like to see an old pal.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Not when he's as likely to be nailed as you are !
sp.stage: Music — Enter Sikes, L. door 2 E.; he takes a seat in silence; they both turn away from him.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: I hear Fagin's taken; is that true ?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Yes. (a pause)

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Well, why don't you speak to me ?—have you got nothing to say to me?—Do you mean to sell me, or let me stay here till the hunt's over.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Stay here if you think you're safe.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Is the—the—-body buried? (they shake their heads) No! then why don't they?—why do they keep such things above ground for ?—hark! what's that! (starts)

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: What's what?

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: That knocking.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: There's no knocking.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: But look at those eyes!—see—see—how they follow me! Dodger, let me set aside of you !

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: Toby, let's go in the other room.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: What, don't you know an old pal?

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: Oh yes, I know you—but don't you come near me. You murdered poor Nance, and if they come here I'll give you up; aye, and I'll do it now. Murder !—help !—down with him ! (Music — springs on Sikes)

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Ha ! you hell-cub, I'll strangle you!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: (interposing) Don't hurt the boy!—don't hurt the boy ! (knocking without, L. U. E.)

sp.speaker: Dodger.
sp.p: He's here—he's here ! Murder !—help !

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Show me some place where I can put this devil's bird. (Toby opens R. D. ; Sikes throws Dodger in who continues to cry, "Help," "Murder"— murmurs without)

sp.speaker: Mr. Brownlow
sp.p: (without, L. U. E.) Open, in the king's name.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Do you hear, Bill ?

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: Is the door down stairs fast?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Double locked and chained, and the panels lined with sheet iron.

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p: (shaking his fist over the wall, L. c.) Then damn you all, do your worst—I'll cheat you yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
sp.p: (without) Twenty guineas to the man who brings a ladder.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Quick, Bill, or you'll be nabbed !

sp.speaker: Sikes.
sp.p:
Ah ! here's a coil of rope! (takes one up) By the window I can lower myself down into the ditch, and then may the devil aid me. (music — gets out of window to the roof of house — loud yells, when he is seen by the mob, L.—Sikes shakes his fist at them, is seen to fasten one end of rope round chimney, and form a noose at the other) I can let myself down to within a
few feet of the ground, and—then damn ye ! catch me if ye can!—stay; let me put this noose under my arms—Ah, that's Nancy! keep your hands off—away, curse you, keep off! keep off!—Ah!
sp.stage: Loses his footing and falls from roof, loud cheers and clapping of hands when he falls — at the same moment the door, L. 2 E. is burst open, Officers enter, with Brownlow, Oliver, Rose Maylie, Mr. Grimwig, &C.

sp.speaker: Mr. B.
Oliver.
sp.p: How can I thank you, sir? words cannot convey to you the gratitude I feel towards you, and the kind friends who have befriended the poor orphan Parish Boy—Oliver Twist!

div.stage: Curtain .

Mr . Bumble.—F irst Dress: —Beadle's dress. Second Dress: — Blue coat, white waistcoat, black breeches.
Noah Claypole.—First Dress: —Charity-boy's dress, badge, cap, &c. Second Dress: —Smock frock, countryman's hat.
Mr .Brownlow.— Green coat, light waistcoat, drab breeches, and stockings, low-crowned turned up black hat.
Mr . Grimwig.—Great coat, drab coat, nankeen breeches and gaiters, silk waistcoat, drab hat.
Fagin .—Old grey coat, black breeches, brown stockings, black waistcoat, black great coat.
The Artful Dodger.—Long-tailed black coat, cord trousers, stripe waistcoat, Blucher boots.
Charley Bates.—Brown jacket, ragged trousers, waistcoat, and cap.
Sykes .—Velveteen jacket, leather breeches, silk waistcoat, low boots, white hat, great coat.
Toby Crackit.—Blue frock coat, leather breeches, top boots buff waistcoat, flash hat.

Nancy .—A showy coloured dress, white cotton apron, coloured shawl, old bonnet, red ribbon, coloured boots. Second Dress: — Brown cotton gown, straw bonnet, coloured handkerchief on neck. Third Dress: —Same as the first.
Mrs . Corney.—Green damask gown, muslin handkerchief, apron and pink ribbon. Second Dress .-—Chintz gown, thick apron handkerchief, shawl, and bonnet.
Rose Maylie .—White muslin high dress, shawl or cloak, and bonnet.
Mrs . Bedwin.—Quaker-coloured silk, white muslin apron, handkerchief and cap, white shawl, black bonnet.
